sentences.sentence: In the middle of this conversation, we heard some of them awake, and soon after we saw two of them on their feet( 站立着 ).
Excited with this, the captain took the bird gun I had given him in his hand, and a pistol( 手枪 ) in his belt.
The two men who were with the captain made some noise, at which one of the seamen who was awake cried out to the rest, but the moment he cried out the three of them fired.
They had so well aimed their shot at the men they knew, that two of them were killed at once.
There were three more in the company, and one of them was slightly wounded.
When they saw their danger, and that it was useless to resist( 反抗 ), they begged for mercy( 宽容 ).
The captain told them he would spare their lives if they would swear( 发誓 ) to be faithful to him in recovering the ship, and afterwards( 后来 ) return back to Jamaica, from where they had come.
They gave him all the promises that could be desired, and he was willing to believe them, and spare their lives.
I only asked him to keep them tied hand and foot while they were on the island.
While this was happening, I sent Friday with the captain’s mate( 大副 ) to the boat with orders to secure( 系紧 ) it.
On the way three more men, who were separated from the rest, came back upon hearing the guns fired.
Seeing the captain was now their captain once more, they agreed to be tied up also, and so our victory was complete.
The captain and I now asked about each other’s situations.
I began first, and told him my whole history, which he heard with amazement( 吃惊 ).
Indeed, as my story is a whole collection of( 一连串 ) wonders, it affected him deeply.
When he reflected on how I seemed to have been preserved there on purpose to save his life, the tears ran down his face, and he could not speak a word more.
All I showed him, all I said to him, was perfectly amazing( 令人惊讶的 ).
I told him this was my castle and my shelter( 住所 ), and that I had a seat( 宅邸 ) in the country, which I would show him too at another time.
At present our business was to consider how to recover the ship.
He agreed with me about that, but told me he had no idea what to do, for that there were still twenty-six men on board the ship.
There would be no attacking them with so small a number as we were.
I thought for some time about what he had said, and decided that the best plan was to lead the men on board into some trap to prevent their attacking us.
Then I thought that in a little while the ship’s crew would begin wondering what had happened to their comrades and the boat.
They would certainly come on shore in their other boat to look for them, and then perhaps they might be too strong for us.
We thus first decided to pull the boat up on the beach, so high that the high tide( 潮 ) would not float it off.
We broke a hole in its bottom so that it could not be used.
As we were thinking what to do, we heard the ship fire a gun several times, making signals to the boat.
At last, when all their signals and firing proved useless, we saw them lower another boat out and row towards the shore.
We saw that there were at least ten men in it, and that they had guns with them.
When we saw the boat coming from the ship, we secured( 保护 ) our prisoners.
Two of them I sent with Friday, who guarded them.
The other prisoners were luckier, and were taken into my service.
With them and the three honest men we were nine men, well armed.
I was sure we should be able to deal with the ten men that were coming.
The captain had said there were three or four honest men among them also.
As soon as they got to the place where their other boat lay, they ran their boat onto the beach and came on shore.
The first thing they did was to run to their other boat, and it was easy to see they were greatly surprised to find a hole in its bottom.
After they had thought a while about this, they sent up two or three great shouts, to try if they could make their companions hear, but without success.
They consulted( 商量 ) together, and left three men in the boat, while the rest went up into the country to look for their companions.
Seven men came on shore. The three who remained in the boat kept it a good distance away from the shore, so that it was impossible for us to come at them in the boat.
Those that came on shore marched towards the top of the little hill, under which my shelter( 住所 ) lay, and while they could not see my cave, we could see them clearly.
We should have been very glad if they had come nearer to us, so that we could have fired at them.
But they shouted till they were tired, and then they sat down together under a tree to think.
We waited a long while, and were very uneasy when we saw them all stand up and walk down towards the sea.
I imagined that they had given up their search, and were going back again.
Presently I thought of a plan to bring them back again, and ordered Friday and the captain’s mate( 大副 ) to go over to the little stream to the west, and call out as loud as they could.
As soon as they heard the seamen answer them, they should shout back again, and draw them as far into the island and among the woods as possible.
The seamen were just going into the boat when Friday and the mate( 大副 ) shouted, and presently the men answered.
The men ran along the shore towards the voice they heard, when they were stopped by the stream, where the water was deep and they could not cross over.
They called for the boat to come and carry them over.
This was all as I expected.
When they had brought the boat a good way into the stream, one of the three men got out, and left only two in the boat.
This was what I wished for, and I took the other men with me, and caught the two men in the boat by surprise.
We needed very few arguments to persuade the two men to surrender( 投降 ), when they saw five men around them.
Besides, these were some of the crew who were not so enthusiastic in the mutiny( 反叛 ) as the rest, and afterwards( 后来 ) they joined very sincerely( 真诚地 ) with us.
In the meantime( 与此同时 ), Friday and the captain’s mate( 大副 ) led the rest of the crew from one place to another.
By the time the men turned back, they could not return to the boat before it was dark.
We had nothing now to do but to watch for( 密切注意 ) them in the dark, and to attack them.
It was several hours before the other men came back to their boat, and we could hear them long before they arrived.
Finally they came back to the boat, but it is impossible to express their confusion( 困惑 ) when they found the boat tied up, and their two men gone.
We could hear them call one to another in a most pathetic( 悲伤的 ) manner, telling one another they had come to a magical island.
I tried my best to capture( 抓住 ) them, so as to kill as few of them as I could.
I brought my men nearer, and ordered Friday and the captain to creep( 爬行 ) in as close to the boat as they could before they threatened( 威胁 ) to fire.
They had not been long in that position when the man who acted as leader of the group came walking towards them.
When the men came nearer, the captain and Friday fired their guns.
The leader was killed upon the spot( 当场 ), and the next man was shot in the body, though he did not die till an hour or two afterward( 之后 ).
At the noise of the guns I immediately advanced with my whole army, which was now eleven men.
